      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void addGlobalRejection(java.util.List<? extends T> states, kotlin.jvm.functions.Function0<java.lang.Boolean> condition)
      Adds a global rejection to the state machine, which will reject all of the given states if the condition is met
      boolean addState(State<?> state)
      Adds a state to this state machine
      AWaitable back()
      Returns the state machine to the state it was in previously
      State<java.lang.String> getElseCondition()
      The state to go to when a state change is requested for a state that doesn't exist
      java.lang.Object getLastState()
      Gets the state that the machine was in last Note that this value is not updated during a state change until the "exit" method of the previous state finishes
      java.lang.Object getState()
      Gets the state that the machine is currently in Note that this value is not updated during a state change until the "exit" method of the previous state finishes
      boolean isInState(T state)
      Checks if a machine is in the given state
      void setElseCondition(State<java.lang.String> p)
      The state to go to when a state change is requested for a state that doesn't exist
      AWaitable setState(T state)
      Sets the state of this machine to the given state. If the machine is already in the given state, no action is taken.
      AWaitable toggle(T state1, T state2)
      Toggles between two states. The logic is as follows: If the machine is in state1, switch to state2. Otherwise, switch to state1 This means that if the machine is in any other state than state1, it will switch to state1.
      boolean wasInState(T state)
      Checks if a machine was in the given state

    • Method Detail

      • addGlobalRejection

        public void addGlobalRejection(java.util.List<? extends T> states,
                               kotlin.jvm.functions.Function0<java.lang.Boolean> condition)

        Adds a global rejection to the state machine, which will reject all of the given states if the condition is met

        Makes cleaner syntax for rejecting a bunch of states for one reason

      • addState

        public boolean addState(State<?> state)

        Adds a state to this state machine

        Parameters:
        state - The state to add

      • getElseCondition

        public State<java.lang.String> getElseCondition()

        The state to go to when a state change is requested for a state that doesn't exist

      • setElseCondition

        public void setElseCondition(State<java.lang.String> p)

        The state to go to when a state change is requested for a state that doesn't exist

      • setState

        public AWaitable setState(T state)

        Sets the state of this machine to the given state. If the machine is already in the given state, no action is taken.

        Parameters:
        state - The state to switch to
        Returns:
        A waitable object that unblocks when the state's "entry" finishes

      • back

        public AWaitable back()

        Returns the state machine to the state it was in previously

      • getState

        public java.lang.Object getState()

        Gets the state that the machine is currently in Note that this value is not updated during a state change until the "exit" method of the previous state finishes

        Returns:
        The state that the machine is currently in

      • getLastState

        public java.lang.Object getLastState()

        Gets the state that the machine was in last Note that this value is not updated during a state change until the "exit" method of the previous state finishes

        Returns:
        The state that the machine was last in

      • isInState

        public boolean isInState(T state)

        Checks if a machine is in the given state

        Parameters:
        state - The state to check
        Returns:
        true if the machine is in this state, false otherwise

      • wasInState

        public boolean wasInState(T state)

        Checks if a machine was in the given state

        Parameters:
        state - The state to check
        Returns:
        true if the machine is in this state, false otherwise

      • toggle

        public AWaitable toggle(T state1,
                        T state2)

        Toggles between two states. The logic is as follows: If the machine is in state1, switch to state2. Otherwise, switch to state1 This means that if the machine is in any other state than state1, it will switch to state1.

        Parameters:
        state1 - State 1 to toggle
        state2 - State 2 to toggle
        Returns:
        The waitable of whatever state was switched to
